review: It gets a 2 star, because it does work and it's cheap.  The big problem is that it barely does anything and what it does is of mediocre quality at best.Contrary to what you may hear,  this device has NO APPS.  All the apps must be installed in your smartphone or tablet (iOS or Android ... not sure WinPho is supported).  The few apps that are available (less than 20) require that the app be active during the cast or the video will pause when the device goes into standby mode (so far only the YouTube app doesn't have this problem). From what I can see,  it needs the active status just to keep track of the playback time.Casting anything from Chrome has a delay (video on Chrome is ahead from what Chromecast displays) ... but I guess that is acceptable.  What is not acceptable is that the delay also includes out of sync audio.  Sometimes is really bad (as in seconds out of sync) others you get about 500ms .... but no matter what you do (or what device you use to cast) you will always have an annoying out of sync audio.  Note:  Casting from Chrome will drain the hell out of anything.  It works like a video capture (of the screen) and is very power hungry.Also, the video casted from Chrome is cropped in all four sides.  It is cropped to the point that 16:9 HD video (that plays perfectly if played natively on the TV) will not show (or will cut in half) subtitles. Google claims that the problem is the TV cropping the HDMI signal ... but it is hard to believe when the same issue happens on EVERY TV and HD monitor in my house.
